title: What Art Does
body: Art is something that happens, a process, not a quality. It is a verb, not a noun. What it does is create a new experience, a different way of seeing the world.

title: The Shape of Design
body: Design is a field of connections—it creates links between things that were previously unconnected. The work is a response to an inquiry.

title: Meteora
body: The album that defined a generation. Raw emotion meets precision engineering—nu-metal at its most vulnerable and powerful.

title: Oblique Strategies
body: Over one hundred worthwhile dilemmas. A card-based method for promoting creativity, created by Brian Eno and Peter Schmidt.

title: The Dark Side of the Moon
body: A prism dispersing light into a spectrum—simple, iconic, eternal. The cover that taught me album art could be fine art.

media.alt: The Dark Side of the Moon album cover showing a prism dispersing white light

title: Music for Airports 1/1
body: The piece that invented ambient music. Designed to induce calm and space to think.

title: Koyaanisqatsi
body: Life out of balance. A wordless documentary that sees humanity through time-lapse eyes, scored by Philip Glass.

title: Four Quartets
body: We shall not cease from exploration, and the end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started and know the place for the first time.

title: Rothko Chapel
body: Fourteen black paintings in an octagonal room. A place for silence and contemplation. Art as sacred space.

media.alt: Interior of the Rothko Chapel showing dark paintings on walls

title: Ico
body: A boy and a girl, escaping a castle. No HUD, no tutorials—just hand-holding and trust. Games as poetry.

title: Rain Room
body: Walk through falling water without getting wet. Technology that responds to presence, creating impossible experiences.
